message: This alert is no longer in force as river levels in the Middle Aire catchment have fallen below levels of concern. Further wintry showers are forecast over the next few days, but we do not expect these to have an impact on river levels. Please continue to take care around low-lying footpaths where standing water may remain.

The flood alert for the Upper Derwent remains in force. Flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around the Low Marishes and Malton area. Levels at Malton are falling slowly but remain high. Further snow showers are forecast over the next few days. Pumping operations continue as required in Old Malton, Malton, and Norton, to manage the impact of groundwater and surface water in the area. High groundwater levels are expected to continue until the end of February 2021. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Please visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation, and will update this message on Tuesday evening 09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

message: The flood alert for the Lower Derwent remains in force as flooding of roads and farmland remains possible. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, particularly around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Elvington, and Bubwith. Levels at Malton are falling slowly but remain high. Flood warnings are in force in the Buttercrambe and Stamford Bridge area. Further snow showers are forecast over the next few days.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Please visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast & current river levels. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Tuesday evening 09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse remains in force, due to high river levels following heavy rain and snowmelt on the upper catchments. River levels at Naburn are falling but remain high. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. See the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on Tuesday evening 09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.
description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby

message: The flood alert for the Upper River Ouse remains in force, as river levels remain high following recent rain and snow melt on the upper catchment. Consequently, flooding of roads, riverside footpaths and farmland remains possible. The River Ouse in York peaked at a level of 3.9m, overnight on Sunday 07/2/2021 and levels are continuing to fall slowly throughout today, Tuesday 09/02/21. The Foss Barrier is in operation and flood gates are closed. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. See the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on Tuesday evening 09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.
riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Wharfe remains in force due to high levels at the confluence between the River Wharfe and the River Ouse. River levels at Tadcaster have fallen, but levels at Cawood on the River Ouse remain high due to a mix of recent rainfall and snowmelt, and are expected to fall through Tuesday morning 09/02/2021. Consequently, flooding of low lying roads and farmland remains possible. We have deployed pumps to Bolton Percy and Nun Appleton as required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Please visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Tuesday evening 09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.

Levels in the River Aire remain high but continue to fall.
Further wintry showers are forecast over the next few days, but we do not expect these to have an impact on river levels. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses or washlands where standing water may remain. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

message: This flood alert for the Lower Swale catchment is no longer in force as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the situation. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels.
riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

message: The flood warning remains in force for the River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill. Flooding of properties is expected. The current river level at Buttercrambe is 1.7m and falling slowly, however levels are expected to remain high throughout today, Tuesday 09/02/2021. Further snow showers are forecast over the next few days. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Please visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Tuesday evening 09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.

The flood warning remains in force for the River Derwent at Stamford Bridge Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge. The risk of flooding remains. The river at Stamford Bridge continues to fall slowly, and is expected to remain high through Tuesday 09/02/21. Further snow showers are forecast over the next few days. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Please visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Tuesday evening 09/02/21, or as the situation changes.
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

message: River levels in the lower Went have started to fall. Levels on the River Don continue to fall, which is allowing the Went doors to open and the levels in the Went around Topham Ferry Bridge to fall. Whilst levels remain high, the risk of flooding to low-lying roads and farmland remains. Further wintry showers are forecast over the next few days but we do not expect these to cause a significant river response. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been in the area checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated at 21:00 09/02/2021 or as the situation changes.
county: Doncaster, East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, Wakefield

message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet remains in force, due to high river levels following heavy rain and snowmelt on the upper catchments. Levels at Cawood are falling slowly, but are expected to remain high today, Tuesday 09/02/21. Flooding of roads and farmland remains possible. Further snow showers are forecast over the next few days. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on Tuesday evening  09/02/2021, or as the situation changes.
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
description: Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet

message: River levels continue to fall across the Lower Aire catchment following the recent heavy rain. Levels within the washlands remain high, so please avoid using footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Although further wintry showers are forecast over the next few days, we do not expect these to cause a significant river response. Our incident response staff continue to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 21:00 today, 09/02/2021 or if the situation changes.
This Flood Alert is no longer in force. For the latest flood warnings and alert information please check gov.uk/flood
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

message: River levels on the River Aire are receding. Subsequently, this flood warning is no longer in force. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

message: This Flood Warning is no longer in force, conditions are improving in the area. See the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and river and sea levels.

message:
River levels on the Lower Aire have started to fall. Levels in West Marsh washlands are still elevated but have also started to fall. The washland will continue to drain as the River Aire levels fall. 
Further wintry showers are forecast over the next few days, but we do not expect these to have an impact on river levels. We continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff have checked defences in the area. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near washlands, and be prepared to act on your flood plan. This message will be updated by 21:00, 09/02/2021 or as the situation changes.
description: River Aire at Hirst Marsh and West Marsh

message: This flood alert has been issued as rainfall over this winter has resulted in increased groundwater levels, and water is emerging in the Gypsey Race catchment. These rising water levels are now affecting local watercourses, low lying land and roads. Impacts are expected to last over the coming days and weeks. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Tuesday evening or as the situation changes.
county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
